text: March 2010
label: BODY

text: The Benefits of Health Care Reform
label: BODY

text: In the 2nd Congressional District of Idaho
label: BODY

text: Committee on Energy and Commerce
label: BODY

text: The U.S. House of Representatives will soon vote on health care reform legislation. This legislation will
label: BODY

text: make health care affordable for the middle class, provide security for seniors, and guarantee access to
label: BODY

text: health insurance for the uninsured – while reducing the federal deficit by over $100 billion over the next
label: BODY

text: decade.  This analysis examines the benefits of the legislation in the 2nd Congressional District of Idaho,
label: BODY

text: which is represented by Rep. Michael K. Simpson.
label: BODY

text: In Rep. Simpson’s district, the health care reform bill will:
label: BODY

text:  Improve coverage for 425,000 residents with health insurance.
label: BODY

text:  Give tax credits and other assistance to up to 191,000 families and 20,100 small businesses to help
label: BODY

text: them afford coverage.
label: BODY

text:  Improve Medicare for 95,000 beneficiaries, including closing the donut hole.
label: BODY

text:  Extend coverage to 80,500 uninsured residents.
label: BODY

text:  Guarantee that 15,900 residents with pre-existing conditions can obtain coverage.
label: BODY

text:  Protect 1,100 families from bankruptcy due to unaffordable health care costs.
label: BODY

text:  Allow 67,000 young adults to obtain coverage on their parents’ insurance plans.
label: BODY

text:  Provide millions of dollars in new funding for 35 community health centers.
label: BODY

text:  Reduce the cost of uncompensated care for hospitals and other health care providers by $104
label: BODY

text: million annually.
label: HH1

text: Affordable High-Quality Health Care for the Middle Class
label: BODY

text: Essential health insurance reforms.  Approximately 62% of the district (425,000 residents) receives
label: HH2

text: health care coverage from an employer or through policies purchased on the individual market.  Under the
label: BODY

text: legislation, individuals with insurance can keep the coverage they have now, and it will get better.  The
label: BODY

text: insurance reforms in the bill prohibit annual and lifetime limits, eliminate rescissions for individuals who
label: BODY

text: become ill while insured, ban coverage denials for pre-existing conditions, and reduce the cost of
label: BODY

text: preventive care.  To rein in soaring insurance costs, the reforms also limit the amount insurance
label: BODY

text: companies can spend on administrative expenses, profits, and other overhead.
label: BODY

text: Historic health care tax cuts.  Those who do not receive health care coverage through their employer
label: BODY

text: will be able to purchase coverage at group rates through the new health insurance exchange.  To make this
label: BODY

text: insurance affordable, the legislation contains the largest middle-class tax cut for health care in history,
label: BODY

text: providing middle class families with incomes up to $88,000 for a family of four with tax credits to help
label: BODY

text: pay for coverage in the exchange.  For a family of four making $50,000, the average tax credit will be
label: BODY

text: approximately $5,800.  There are 191,000 households in the district that could qualify for these credits if
label: BODY

text: they purchase health insurance through the exchange or, in the case of households with incomes below
label: BODY

text: 133% of poverty, receive coverage through Medicaid.
label: BODY

text: Coverage for individuals with pre-existing conditions.  There are 15,900 uninsured individuals in the
label: HH2

text: district who have pre-existing medical conditions like cancer, heart disease, and diabetes.  Under the bill’s
label: BODY

text: insurance reforms, they cannot be denied affordable coverage.
label: BODY

text: Financial security for families.  There were 1,100 health care-related bankruptcies in the district in 2008,
label: HH3

text: caused primarily by the health care costs not covered by insurance.  The bill caps annual out-of-pocket
label: BODY

text: costs at $6,200 for individuals and $12,400 for families who purchase insurance through the exchange or
label: BODY

text: who are insured by small businesses.  It also eliminates annual and lifetime limits on all insurance
label: BODY

text: coverage.  These reforms ensure that no family will have to face financial ruin because of high health care
label: BODY

text: costs.
label: BODY

text: Security for Seniors
label: BODY

text: Improving Medicare.  There are 95,000 Medicare beneficiaries in the district.  The legislation improves
label: HH2

text: their benefits by providing free preventive and wellness care, improving primary and coordinated care,
label: BODY

text: and enhancing nursing home care.  The bill also strengthens the Medicare Trust Fund, extending its
label: BODY

text: solvency from 2017 to 2026.
label: BODY

text: Closing the Part D donut hole.  Each year, 9,400 Medicare beneficiaries in the district enter the Part D
label: BODY

text: donut hole and are forced to pay the full cost of their prescription drugs.  Under the bill, these
label: BODY

text: beneficiaries will receive a $250 rebate in 2010, 50% discounts on brand name drugs beginning in 2011,
label: BODY

text: and complete closure of the donut hole within a decade.  A typical beneficiary who enters the donut hole
label: BODY

text: will see savings of over $700 in 2011 and over $3,000 by 2020.
label: BODY

text: New Coverage Options for Young Adults
label: BODY

text: New lower-cost health care options for young adults.  The legislation will allow young adults to remain
label: BODY

text: on their parents’ policies until they turn 26.  There are 67,000 young adults in the district who could
label: BODY

text: benefit from this option.  For individuals under age 30, the bill creates new, inexpensive policies that
label: BODY

text: allow them to obtain protection from catastrophic health care costs.
label: BODY

text: Helping Small Businesses
label: BODY

text: Helping small businesses obtain health insurance.  Under the legislation, small businesses with 100
label: HH2

text: employees or less will be able to join the health insurance exchange, benefiting from group rates and a
label: BODY

text: greater choice of insurers.  There are 21,600 small businesses in the district that could benefit from this
label: BODY

text: provision.
label: BODY

text: Tax credits for small businesses.  Small businesses with 25 employees or less and average wages of less
label: BODY

text: than $50,000 will qualify for tax credits of up to 50% of the costs of providing health insurance.  There
label: BODY

text: are up to 20,100 small businesses in the district that could qualify for these credits.
label: BODY

text: Covering the Uninsured
label: BODY

text: Coverage of the uninsured.  The legislation would extend coverage to 95% of all Americans.  If this
label: BODY

text: level of coverage is reached in the district, 80,500 residents who currently do not have health insurance
label: BODY

text: will receive coverage.
label: BODY

text: Relieving the burden of uncompensated care.  In 2008, health care providers in the district provided
label: HH2

text: uncompensated care to individuals who lacked insurance coverage and were unable to pay their bills.
label: BODY

text: Under the legislation, these costs of uncompensated care will be reduced by $104 million.
label: BODY

text: Supporting community health centers.  There are 35 community health centers in the district that
label: HH3

text: provide health care to the poor and medically underserved.  Nationwide, the legislation would provide
label: BODY

text: $11 billion in new funding for these centers.  If the community health centers in the district receive the
label: BODY

text: average level of support, the 35 centers will receive $45.5 million in new assistance.
label: BODY

text: Deficit Responsibility
label: BODY

text: No deficit spending.  The cost of health care reform under the legislation is fully paid for, in large part by
label: BODY

text: eliminating waste, fraud, abuse, and excessive profits for private insurers.  The legislation will reduce the
label: BODY

text: deficit by $130 billion over the next ten years, and by about $1.2 trillion over the second decade.
label: BODY

text: This analysis is based upon the following sources:  the U.S. Census (data on insurance rates, small
label: BODY

text: businesses, and young adult population); the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (data on
label: BODY

text: Medicare and Part D enrollment); the Department of Health and Human Services (data on health care-
label: BODY

text: related bankruptcies, uncompensated care, and pre-existing conditions); the Health Resources and
label: BODY

text: Services Administration (data on community health centers); and the Congressional Budget Office
label: BODY

text: (estimates of the percentage of citizens with health insurance coverage under health care reform
label: BODY

text: legislation).
label: BODY
